learning_outcomes.description: Show a familiarity with contemporary Australian archaeological research, including current best practice.
Recognise the major themes, case studies and concepts of archaeology in the greater Australian region.
Describe the general characteristics of occupation in Australia.

Apply skills in archaeological interpretation, critical thinking, and expository written presentations relating to key issues, including ethics, in Australian archaeology and its professional practice.
Explain the significance of key archaeological sites in Australia.
Recognise how your background and worldview may influence your understandings and perspectives of the past.

assessments.task_description:
These reflections are due at 2pm on the due date. Over the course of the semester, you will write 4 reflections, which are worth 20% of your overall mark. Each reflection is worth 5% and is to be 300 ± 50 words equivalent. Each reflection will be themed on a different aspect of the course and will document your growth of knowledge and personal perspectives on archaeological practice in Australia.

Each reflection will be marked on the criteria of:

  • Clarity of your answer
  • Authenticity
  • Presentation 

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: In-class exam held during your lecture
assessments.due_date:
11/05/2026

The exam will take place during the lecture, beginning at 11am.
assessments.task_description:
Duration: 90 minutes, held in-class, during your regular lecture time, beginning at 11am. 

This will be a comprehensive exam based on the lecture content, required readings, and in-class discussions/activities from weeks 1-10, comprising 27 questions in total. The exam format will be:

  • 15 Multiple Choice questions: a question or statement will be provided with possible answers; students must select the best single answer.
  • 10 Short Answer questions: answers consisting of a single word, sentence or short paragraph.
  • 2 Short Essay questions: each essay to consist of 1-2 (legible) written pages. 

Please note that short essay questions will be provided each week, relating to the content of that week. You will be able to formulate answers for these essay questions, yourself, over the course of the semester. From the list of provided short essay questions, two short essay questions will be chosen for the in-class exam. 

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard Ultra for this course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment task is to be completed in-person during the normal lecture time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.mode: Activity/ Performance, Oral, Product/ Artefact/ Multimedia, Written
assessments.task_description:
For this final assessment piece, you will create a recorded 5 minute presentation (+/- 20 seconds) on a significant Australian site. Your audience will be the general public and you will need to consider how to convey the importance and significance of your site in straightforward language. In your presentation, you will provide background to the site, explain why it is significant, and link it to broader research themes in Australian archaeology. You will record your presentation and then submit your recording as an ECHO360 video. In addition to the 5 minute video presentation, you will need to submit your script (with in-text references and a reference list at the end) through turnitin. 

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Course introduction and Contemporary Practice

Welcome to our first lecture in ARCA2020, where we'll begin by outlining the course structure, including assessment requirements and our commitment to respectful engagement with Indigenous cultural heritage. The first half of today's lecture will cover practical aspects of the course, including the assessment breakdown: four short reflections (20%), an in-person and in-semester exam (50%), and a recorded presentation (30%). In the second half, we'll explore contemporary archaeological practice in Australia, and discussing current best practices in stakeholder engagement and consultation.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Course introduction and Contemporary Practice Welcome to our first lecture in ARCA2020, where we'll begin by outlining the course structure, including assessment requirements and our commitment to respectful engagement with Indigenous cultural heritage. The first half of today's lecture will cover practical aspects of the course, including the assessment breakdown: four short reflections (20%), an in-person and in-semester exam (50%), and a recorded presentation (30%). In the second half, we'll explore contemporary archaeological practice in Australia, and discussing current best practices in stakeholder engagement and consultation.

learning_activities.topic:
Introductory Tutorial

In our first tutorial, we'll begin by sharing some information about ourselves, such as our names, backgrounds, and personal connections to place - this helps us understand the diverse perspectives we bring to this course and to learning about Australasian archaeology. Through these introductions, we'll also explore how language and terminology in Australian archaeology has evolved, particularly focusing on respectful ways to acknowledge and discuss Indigenous heritage and cultural materials. We will discuss your experiences of undertaking the Implicit Association Test on the Diversity Australia website and consider how unconscious biases might affect archaeological interpretations. The tutorial will conclude with guidance on your first assessment task - a short reflection that helps you to start considering your own positionality as an emerging archaeologist and how your background might influence your interpretation of archaeological evidence.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Introductory Tutorial In our first tutorial, we'll begin by sharing some information about ourselves, such as our names, backgrounds, and personal connections to place - this helps us understand the diverse perspectives we bring to this course and to learning about Australasian archaeology. Through these introductions, we'll also explore how language and terminology in Australian archaeology has evolved, particularly focusing on respectful ways to acknowledge and discuss Indigenous heritage and cultural materials. We will discuss your experiences of undertaking the Implicit Association Test on the Diversity Australia website and consider how unconscious biases might affect archaeological interpretations. The tutorial will conclude with guidance on your first assessment task - a short reflection that helps you to start considering your own positionality as an emerging archaeologist and how your background might influence your interpretation of archaeological evidence.

What is the history of thought behind how we understand the past?

learning_activities.topic:
Who Owns the Past?

"Who Owns the Past?" This question first gained prominence in the early 1980s (and edited into an internationally-significant volume by Isabella McBryde in 1985) and remains a salient provocation. What does archaeology in a post-colonial nations look like? Would archaeology exist without colonialism? Who has the right to tell the narrative of the past?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Who Owns the Past? "Who Owns the Past?" learning_activities.topic:
QLD heritage legislation and cultural heritage; panel Q&A with industry experts

First Hour: Dr Michael Aird (Senior Research Fellow, UQ) will discuss Queensland heritage legislation. The protection of Indigenous cultural sites in Queensland has evolved through three major legislative stages, though each fell short of adequate protection. Beginning with the Aboriginal Relics Preservation Act 1967 , legislation offered Indigenous sites virtually no meaningful safeguards. Twenty years later, the Cultural Record (Landscapes Queensland and Queensland Estate) Act 1987 marked a shift as archaeologists started building formal partnerships with Indigenous communities, yet the Act still lacked teeth when it came to actual site protection. The current framework, the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003, represented progress by granting Indigenous communities greater control over their heritage. However, it remains fundamentally compromised, continuing to prioritise development interests over the preservation of cultural sites.

Second Hour: So you want to be an archaeologist? Q&A with a panel of industry experts -- come prepared with your questions about what it is like to be a professional archaeologist and how you might best prepare yourself for seeking a job.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: QLD heritage legislation and cultural heritage; panel Q&A with industry experts

The protection of Indigenous cultural sites in Queensland has evolved through three major legislative stages, though each fell short of adequate protection. Beginning with the Aboriginal Relics Preservation Act 1967 , legislation offered Indigenous sites virtually no meaningful safeguards. Twenty years later, the Cultural Record (Landscapes Queensland and Queensland Estate) Act 1987 marked a shift as archaeologists started building formal partnerships with Indigenous communities, yet the Act still lacked teeth when it came to actual site protection. The current framework, the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act 2003 , represented progress by granting Indigenous communities greater control over their heritage. However, it remains fundamentally compromised, continuing to prioritise development interests over the preservation of cultural sites. Second Hour: So you want to be an archaeologist? Q&A with a panel of industry experts -- come prepared with your questions about what it is like to be a professional archaeologist and how you might best prepare yourself for seeking a job.

learning_activities.topic:
Ethics in Archaeology

In May 2020, Rio Tinto legally blew up the Juukan Gorge archaeology sites. While it was legal, public outcry demonstrated the ethically fraught nature of this act. In this tutorial we will talk about ethics and archaeology.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Ethics in Archaeology In May 2020, Rio Tinto legally blew up the Juukan Gorge archaeology sites. While it was legal, public outcry demonstrated the ethically fraught nature of this act. In this tutorial we will talk about ethics and archaeology.

learning_activities.topic:
Into Sahul

In this lecture we begin our deeper dive into what we know about the early archaeology of Sahul. In this lecture, we will explore what we know (and don't know!) about settlement routes into Sunda and Sahul, along with early sites of northern Sahul

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
What happened to the the megafauna?

Australia was populated by a diverse array of large reptiles, birds and marsupials that have all but disappeared. When did they disappear and what explanations have been suggested for the mechanism of their disappearance? In this guest lecture by Associate Professor Gilbert Price, he will discuss what we know about late Pleistocene megafauna and possible extinction drivers.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: What happened to the the megafauna? Australia was populated by a diverse array of large reptiles, birds and marsupials that have all but disappeared. When did they disappear and what explanations have been suggested for the mechanism of their disappearance? In this guest lecture by Associate Professor Gilbert Price, he will discuss what we know about late Pleistocene megafauna and possible extinction drivers.

learning_activities.topic:
Public holiday: on-line recorded lecture: Inland economies and technological strategies

This lecture is recorded and online only, as Monday May 5 is a public holiday.

Change & variability in Australian temperate to arid zones, how has change in stone artefact technologies been identified and explained? What are some of the models used to explain this change and what do changes imply about past human culture and behaviour?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
